Column Comment.0: EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a specific piece of equipment.
Column Comment.1: ACQUIRE DATE NEW: The date this new piece of equipment was acquired.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: EQUIPMENT CATALOGUE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the list of kinds ofequipment. Think of this as a catalogue or brochure that shows all the kinds ofequipment that you may use, but may or may not actually have. Actual pieces ofequipment thatexist are defined in the table EQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.4: COMMISSION DATE: The date when this piece of equipment was commissioned.
Column Comment.5: OWNER BA ID: Unique identifier for the current owner of this equipment.
Column Comment.6: DECOMMISSION DATE: The date when this piece of equipment wasdecommissioned.
Column Comment.7: DESCRIPTION: a textual description of the equipment.
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date on which this row of data first came into effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.9: EQUIPMENT GROUP: The functional group of equipment types, such as vehicles,drilling rigs, measuring equipment, monitoring equipment etc. Note that the functionof this table may also be assumed by the CLASSIFICATION module for more robustand complete classifications. If you are using CAT EQUIPMENT modules, you maynot need to populate this column, as the information will be in CAT EQUIPMENTalready.
Column Comment.10: EQUIPMENT NAME: For specific types of equipment that are assigned names, suchas rigs. This column should not be used to identify the type of equipment this is.
Column Comment.11: EQUIPMENT TYPE: the type of equipment that is listed, can be grouped into broadclassifications with R CAT EQUIP GROUP if you wish. Note that the function of thistable may also be assumed by the CLASSIFICATION module for more robust andcomplete classifications. If you are using CAT EQUIPMENT modules, you may notneed to populate this column, as the information will be in CAT EQUIPMENT already.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: MANUFACTURER BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for thebusiness associate who manufactured this piece of equipment.
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: PURCHASE DATE: The date that this piece of equipment was purchased.
Column Comment.16: EQUIPMENT REFERENCE NUMBER: A reference number that is assigned toequipment, particularly if that number is not the same as the serial number.
Column Comment.17: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.18: SERIAL NUMBER: For equipment that is assigned a serial number, usuallypermanently affixed to a piece of equipment.
Column Comment.19: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.20: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.21: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.22: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.23: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.24: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.25: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.26: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
